meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The <kanji>South</kanji> <kanji>East</kanji> is the <vocabulary>Southeast</vocabulary>.

Remember how 手 can mean a "doer" in some words? What do you think your <kanji>help</kanji> <kanji>doer</kanji> is? It’s someone who helps you, so it’s your <vocabulary>assistant</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>helper</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>aide</vocabulary>.

If it's you <kanji>versus</kanji> someone else and you're <kanji>stand</kanji>ing in each other's way, you're in <vocabulary>conflict</vocabulary>. Better hope they're not bigger than you, or this <vocabulary>confrontation</vocabulary> might turn out to be a bad idea…

対立 is when two sides are in conflict, usually because their ideas, goals, or interests just don't match. It's the kind of <vocabulary>opposition</vocabulary> where neither side wants to back down, and they just keep standing against each other.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>decide</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to decide</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>begin</kanji> or <kanji>start</kanji>, and the verb version is <vocabulary>to begin</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to begin something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to start</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to start something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You start something. Like studying! You should have started studying earlier though, huh?

The kanji for 苦 means <kanji>suffering</kanji>. This word, however, is a bit different, but you'll see how it's related. It means <vocabulary>bitter tasting</vocabulary>. Think of putting the most <vocabulary>bitter</vocabulary> thing in the world in your mouth. You feel sick, your mouth gets all weird, and you try to spit it out but the bitterness remains. Obviously eating bitter tasting things will cause you to suffer.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Give A Ride To Someone
To Give A Lift To Someone

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>ride</kanji> so this word has to do with riding. There's another word that's similar (乗る which means to ride). This particular one is transitive, meaning there is a direct object. The action is done to someone or something. So this means <vocabulary>to give someone a ride</vocabulary> when it's used for people, and <vocabulary>to place something on</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to load something</vocabulary> when it's used for things. 

Use the せ as a hint. The せ is a "sail" (せ) that you use on your boat to give someone a ride. How nice of you.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>heavy</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>heavy</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wake up</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to wake up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get up</vocabulary>.

This word also has a secondary meaning of <vocabulary>to occur</vocabulary>. Think of it this way: when an action "wakes up", in a way it is occurring as well.

Doing something both <kanji>fast</kanji> and <kanji>early</kanji> probably requires you to do it <vocabulary>at once</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>immediately</vocabulary>. Whatever it is, be sure to do it <vocabulary>without delay</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>fast</kanji>ness <kanji>degree</kanji> is your <vocabulary>speed</vocabulary>. 

You use 速度 to talk about a specific speed of something like a car or a train. If you want to talk about speed more casually, you can just say スピード or 速さ.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>distribute</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to distribute</vocabulary>.

This is just the noun version of the kanji 酒 - it has an お there to be nice. This word can mean both <vocabulary>alcohol</vocabulary> (like the parent kanji) or <vocabulary>sake</vocabulary> (the main kind of Japanese alcohol, at least back in the kanji days).

You know that 日本 is "Japan" so when you add <kanji>alcohol</kanji> onto the end of that you have <vocabulary>Japanese Style Alcohol</vocabulary> (what's the big Japanese style alcohol that everyone knows? That's <vocabulary>sake</vocabulary>).

A <kanji>sick</kanji> <kanji>institution</kanji> is a place where sick people go. That is a <vocabulary>hospital</vocabulary>.

病院 is a broad word used to talk about not just big hospitals but also regular <vocabulary>doctor's office</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>clinic</vocabulary>s. So when Japanese people speak English, they might say "hospital" even when they are just going to a small, local clinic.
A <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>institution</kanji> is an <vocabulary>academy</vocabulary>. That's where all the fancy people study, anyways.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>end</kanji>, so this verb means <vocabulary>to end</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be over</vocabulary>.

Verbs ending in okurigana that rhyme with ある tend to be intransitive, and 終わる is usually intransitive too. But sometimes it can be transitive and take a direct object. Kind of like "to end" in English — you can say the class ends (intransitive) or a teacher ends their class (transitive).

The <kanji>end</kanji> <kanji>point</kanji> is where everything ends... but for this example, think of a map with a route on it. The last spot on the route is the "last point." It is the <vocabulary>last stop</vocabulary>.

It's the <kanji>end</kanji>. It's the <kanji>finish</kanji>. This word means <vocabulary>end</vocabulary>. Or <vocabulary>finish</vocabulary>! How convenient.

Note that 終了 is slightly more formal than 終わる.
The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>end</kanji> thing is the <vocabulary>last</vocabulary> thing. It is mainly used to refer to the <vocabulary>last</vocabulary> of an ordered sequence.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>learn</kanji> so the vocab verb version means <vocabulary>to learn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take lessons in</vocabulary> something.

You know the kanji here means revolve. The verb version of this is similar. It means to roll or to tumble. You have to be revolving in order to roll or tumble, right? 転がる is intransitive, so it doesn't take a direct object. A ball rolls down a hill. A tumbleweed tumbles. No direct object, right? Verbs ending in okurigana that rhyme with ある tend to be intransitive like this. You can remember this because if something is ある, it's just there, existing, not acting on anything else. That's why verbs that sound like it are often intransitive too!

A <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>revolving</kanji> <kanji>car</kanji>. You'd think this would be a regular car, but <vocabulary>bicycles</vocabulary> were probably introduced before cars were, meaning the self revolving car is the bicycle, not the car. Just imagine yourself on a bike, and you don't even have to move the pedals. They revolve themselves, but now you're going too fast and it's scary.

A thing that <kanji>carries</kanji> <kanji>rotation</kanji>s (think wheels!) is most kinds of vehicles. So, it's kind of like saying you're "doing vehicles" here... but that doesn't make sense. What do you do to vehicles though? You drive them. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to drive</vocabulary>.

You <kanji>revolve</kanji> something, making it roll, and then <kanji>send</kanji> it off somewhere. This means you’re <vocabulary>transfer</vocabulary>ring or forwarding it to someone else.

転送 is often used in the context of logistics or communication systems, like transferring packages or forwarding e-mails.

You <kanji>revolve</kanji> X number of <kanji>times</kanji>. Really, the times isn't so important, but the revolving is. That's why this word is <vocabulary>revolve</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rotate</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>advance</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to advance</vocabulary>.

進む is an intransitive verb, meaning it describes something or someone moving (む) forward. It can be used for physical movement, like a person walking forward or a clock running fast, or for abstract progress, like in someone's work or studies.
Think of things that <kanji>advance</kanji> and <kanji>change</kanji>. Does this sound familiar? Does this sound like <vocabulary>evolution</vocabulary>?

When something <kanji>advance</kanji>s and <kanji>go</kanji>es, it is moving forward. So this means <vocabulary>advance</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>progress</vocabulary>.

進行 can be used to describe various situations, like when a project progresses; but also when an illness advances to a more serious stage.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fall</kanji> and the vocab verb version means <vocabulary>to fall down</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to fall</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>to drop</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>to fail</vocabulary>, in the sense of failing an exam.

A <kanji>young</kanji> <kanji>leaf</kanji> is exactly what you'd expect, although most people usually just call them <vocabulary>fresh leaves</vocabulary>.

Remember how there's some overlap between blue and green in Japanese? 青葉 is another example!  That's why 青 is used to describe fresh and lush green leaves, especially those on trees during early summer.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>lightweight</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>lightweight</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>carry</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to carry</vocabulary>.

The いい portion means "good." So, when what you <kanji>carry</kanji> is good you are <vocabulary>lucky</vocabulary>. Just think of it in terms of luck being a physical item you carry in your hands. Now imagine yourself carrying it. Now think to yourself "what I'm carrying is good, it's lucky!"

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>open</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to open something</vocabulary>.

When something is <kanji>public</kanji> <kanji>open</kanji> it is <vocabulary>open to the public</vocabulary>. You can go look at things that are 公開. You can also use this when you're <vocabulary>releasing</vocabulary> something to the public, which means you’re making it publicly accessible.

This is one of those words that has kanji that basically tell you the meaning. You <kanji>open</kanji> a <kanji>business</kanji>... aka <vocabulary>opening a business</vocabulary>.

While this can be used for opening any sort of business, it’s commonly associated with doctors, lawyers, and other professionals opening their own practice or office.

You are now <kanji>open</kanji> for <kanji>departure</kanji>. You get on your boat and leave this place. You are going to another place to start its <vocabulary>development</vocabulary>, where you will create a new world.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>collect</kanji> and this verb is transitive, meaning the action is done to something or someone. So this verb means things like <vocabulary>to collect something</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to gather something</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>collect</kanji> to the <kanji>middle</kanji> of yourself, you are collecting towards your brain. All energy is going towards there, massing up in the middle, giving you extreme <vocabulary>concentration</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>focus</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>collect</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> you are <vocabulary>collecting money</vocabulary> (or doing <vocabulary>money collection</vocabulary>). Of course, back in the day gold was like money, which is why this word works the way it does. Hopefully you don't have to deal with too much 集金 in your daily life. We'll try to keep WaniKani nice and reasonably priced for you.

集金 often refers to collecting bills, dues, or fees in person or through a designated representative. This can be carried out by a business, an organization, or even just a small group of people.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>drink</kanji> so the vocab verb version is <vocabulary>to drink</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>business</kanji> of <kanji>industry</kanji> is... well... <vocabulary>industry</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>Chinese</kanji> <kanji>letter</kanji>s... you're finally learning the word for them, the thing you've been studying this whole time for so long! This is <vocabulary>kanji</vocabulary>, your new best friend (they came from China, which is why they're Chinese letters).
A <kanji>road</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> is obviously the best kind of road. It's double road, after all. So, what is this ultimate road? It is a <vocabulary>paved road</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>line</kanji> that runs on a <kanji>road</kanji> is a <vocabulary>railroad track</vocabulary>. First you have to get into your mind that the "line" in question is a railway line. Then, what railway line runs on a road and what kind of road is it? It's a <vocabulary>railroad track</vocabulary>.

If you think about it, an <kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> isn't going to be the main road. It will be the road less traveled. You could call it a <vocabulary>path</vocabulary> (you know, like a dirt path!) or a <vocabulary>dirt road</vocabulary>. Alternatively, another less traveled street that would probably be made out of dirt back in the day (before everything was paved) would be an <vocabulary>alley</vocabulary>. Imagine yourself walking down a dirt alley at night with no shoes. Scary!

In the olden days, the <kanji>peoples</kanji> who worked in the <kanji>farm</kanji> were the <vocabulary>peasants</vocabulary>.

農民 means <vocabulary>farmers</vocabulary>, but usually not in the modern sense of people who do farm work as their day job. Instead, it refers to the <vocabulary>farming class</vocabulary> — people who were born into a life of farming, often in historical contexts.

What's another way to call the <kanji>farming</kanji> <kanji>business</kanji>? If you encapsulated it into one word (assuming we're talking about plant farming, here), you could call it <vocabulary>agriculture</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>ground</kanji> <kanji>below</kanji> <kanji>iron</kanji> is iron under the ground. It isn't a deposit of iron, though. It's man-made. And what's made of iron? Trains. In this case, because it's underground, it's a <vocabulary>subway</vocabulary>. Depending on where you live, you might call it <vocabulary>the Underground</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>the Tube</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>the Metro</vocabulary>

A <kanji>man</kanji> made of <kanji>iron</kanji> is a <vocabulary>strong man</vocabulary>... aka a huge <vocabulary>badass</vocabulary>. Have you seen "Iron Chef?" The Japanese translation is 料理の鉄人, which means "Chef Iron Man" aka "Chef Badass," at least in my book.

The <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>iron</kanji> sounds scary, but if you think to back in the day and to where iron was used a lot, you probably think of the railway systems... big hunky pieces of iron on the ground to make the railway. So, you can advance this by adding electricity instead of coal, creating an <vocabulary>electric railway</vocabulary>.
One of the kanji's meanings is <kanji>song</kanji> and this word means exactly that: a <vocabulary>song</vocabulary>.
Remember how  手 can sometimes mean “doer”? What do you think a <kanji>song</kanji> <kanji>doer</kanji> is? A <vocabulary>singer</vocabulary>, of course
What is it called when you <kanji>calculate</kanji> <kanji>numbers</kanji>? That is the study of <vocabulary>math</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>arithmetic</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hear</kanji> so the vocab verb version is <vocabulary>to hear</vocabulary>.

This can also mean <vocabulary>to ask</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to listen</vocabulary>, like asking someone a question or listening to what others are saying. It basically covers anything that involves the act of letting something in through the 門 (gates) of your 耳 (ears).

The <kanji>new</kanji> <kanji>hear</kanji> is what it sounds like. It's new things that you're hearing about in your ear... at least that's what it was back a long time ago. Now those new things that get to your ear get to you via other mediums. In this case, a <vocabulary>newspaper</vocabulary>.
You know 日本 is "Japan." So, when you add <kanji>language</kanji> onto the end of that you have <vocabulary>Japanese language</vocabulary>.
I bet you can guess that フランス means "France." So what happens when you add <kanji>language</kanji> to it? You get the "France Language" aka the <vocabulary>French Language</vocabulary>.

You can probably figure out that スペイン is "Spain" just by reading it. Add the kanji <kanji>language</kanji> on there and you have the <vocabulary>Spanish language</vocabulary> (or just <vocabulary>Spanish</vocabulary>), if you'd like.
The <kanji>main</kanji> thing you talk about in your <kanji>language</kanji> becomes the <vocabulary>subject</vocabulary> of the sentence.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>read</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to read</vocabulary>.

You know that this has something to do with <kanji>read</kanji>ing and you know that 方 means <kanji>way</kanji> or <kanji>method</kanji>. So, when you think of a "way of reading" you can think of a couple other better words, such as <vocabulary>reading</vocabulary> (aka the reading of a word) or <vocabulary>pronunciation</vocabulary>. Anytime you need to know how something sounds, this is what you'll ask for.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>chirp</kanji> but the verb has the broader meaning <vocabulary>to make an animal sound</vocabulary>. Variations of this include <vocabulary>to bark</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to chirp</vocabulary>, but this can be used for any animal sound.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This also works for "train lines" as well. You'll see this attached onto the ends of names describing them.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Please note that this word refers to "the side of something." Not "the left side," for example. That would be 左側.

Imagine yourself <kanji>investigating</kanji> a <kanji>child</kanji>. You heard this child was having a rough time, so you need to come check on the <vocabulary>condition</vocabulary> of his home and life. You find the condition to be terrible, and you tell the parents you have to take the child away because of these conditions (imagine them being ridiculously bad... perhaps they raise raccoons in their kitchen?).

If you use a <kanji>strong</kanji> <kanji>tone</kanji> on certain words, then you are putting <vocabulary>emphasis</vocabulary> on whatever it is you're talking about. It's the <vocabulary>stress</vocabulary> you put on things that are important because your tone gets stronger on those words or syllables.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>investigate</kanji> so the vocab verb version means <vocabulary>to investigate</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

This is a single kanji with some kana and an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>intimacy</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>intimate</vocabulary>! Depending on the context, this also means <vocabulary>friendly</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>close</vocabulary>.

When your <kanji>parent</kanji>s <kanji>cut</kanji> you you'd think they are being mean... but they're not. They are bleeding all the bad blood out of you. They are truly being <vocabulary>kind</vocabulary>. 

Just think of how crazy it would be for your parents to cut you... then think about some kind of twist to make it so they are being kind instead.

A <kanji>friend</kanji> who is like one of your <kanji>parent</kanji>s is someone who will look out for you. They are like family, in fact! That's why this word means <vocabulary>best friend</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>close friend</vocabulary>. Just imagine someone who watches over you like a parent would. This is the way to describe them.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The thing that is <kanji>attach</kanji>ed to your <kanji>face</kanji> isn't a big booger or anything like that. It's something that's always there. It's your <vocabulary>expression</vocabulary>.
When your <kanji>energy</kanji> is that of <kanji>sick</kanji>ness, you are probably <vocabulary>sick</vocabulary>.

As you can probably imagine, when you add the kanji <kanji>sick</kanji> to another word, you're saying what kind of <vocabulary>sickness</vocabulary> it is; you are mentioning what <vocabulary>disease</vocabulary> it is.
A <kanji>person</kanji> who is <kanji>sick</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sick person</vocabulary>. They are also a <vocabulary>patient</vocabulary>, at least we can hope they are, for their sake.

This is the adverb version of the kanji, so it has the same meaning, basically. You can say this is <vocabulary>the most</vocabulary> or just <vocabulary>most</vocabulary>. You can also use it as <vocabulary>extremely</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>tall</kanji> isn't literally the most tall. When you think of something high above the rest, you think of something that is <vocabulary>the best</vocabulary>.
The thing that is the <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>after</kanji> everything else is at the very <vocabulary>end</vocabulary>. It is the <vocabulary>last</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>nearby</kanji> is something that happened close to now. It happened <vocabulary>recently</vocabulary>.

当てる means "to guess" or "to hit", and 字 means <kanji>letter</kanji>. So these are guessed letters? Kind of, they're so-called <vocabulary>phonetic kanji</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>ateji</vocabulary>.

This refers to cases where kanji are used solely for their sound, but not their meaning. There are also some cases of ateji where kanji are used only for their meaning and not their sound, but this is less common.

When things happen in a <kanji>next</kanji>, <kanji>next</kanji> (next, next, next…) way, they happen <vocabulary>one after another</vocabulary>.

Imagine a factory line for item checking. The people there keep shouting "Next! Next!" because items come <vocabulary>in succession</vocabulary> without stopping!

You know the kanji is <kanji>substitute</kanji>, and you know this is a verb. There are other similar ones, but this one means <vocabulary>to replace something</vocabulary>. In order to remember that this particular word means "to replace something" focus in on the え. You have an egg in your hands that you notice isn't any good (it's black and moldy). So, you replace it with another egg (or substitute it with another egg, or exchange it with another egg, etc).

This verb is transitive, meaning it has a direct object. You replace something, like that egg!
Do you remember 医者 (doctor)? What happens when you add <kanji>eye</kanji> on there? You have yourself an <vocabulary>eye doctor</vocabulary>.

You've seen 一番 (number one), so what in the world is this eye on the end? This eye (目) is used to mark something's position in a sequence. So, add this to "number one" and you have <vocabulary>the first thing</vocabulary> or simply <vocabulary>the first</vocabulary>.

Just imagine your collection of eyeballs you have at home. (You have a collection of eyeballs, right?) You have them lined up in a display case and you're explaining the first one to your friend. It's not first because it's the best or anything — you love all your eyeballs equally, after all — but it does happen to come first in sequence in your display right now.

You've seen the word 楽しい, which means "fun." This is obviously very similar looking, though this one means <vocabulary>looking forward to</vocabulary>. Why? Because it has a み on the end, saying "who is going to have fun? It's <reading>me</reading>! That's why I'm looking forward to it!"

You've hopefully seen 向く and 向ける by now. They mean "to face" and "to turn toward." This has a similar idea. When you add 向け to something imagine you're turning it, aiming it at someone. It's aimed at them, meaning it's <vocabulary>made for</vocabulary> them. Turn a book toward someone, now it's <vocabulary>aimed at</vocabulary> them, it's made for them. See the connection?

You've seen that 研究 is "research" from previous vocab, and you might remember 所 can mean "facility." So this word means <vocabulary>research institute</vocabulary> or, of course, <vocabulary>research facility</vocabulary>.

Taking the <kanji>nearby</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> will get you to your destination more quickly (because it's more close by!). This is a <vocabulary>shortcut</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>short way</vocabulary>.

You know that 助ける means "to help." This word, 助かる, is related, but it's a bit different. It means to be helped or to be saved. It's intransitive, so it doesn't take a direct object. Imagine shouting "I'm saved!" No direct object, right? Verbs ending in okurigana that rhyme with ある tend to be intransitive like this. You can remember this because if something is ある, it's just there, existing, not acting on anything else. That's why verbs that sound like it are often intransitive too!

You've hopefully seen the word 楽しい, which means "fun." This is basically the verb version (ends in an う sound, right?) of that. That means this is <vocabulary>to enjoy something</vocabulary>, or just <vocabulary>to have fun</vocabulary>.

You know that you're <kanji>throw</kanji>ing something that is <kanji>attach</kanji>ing to something else. How else can you say that? The best way would be to say <vocabulary>to throw against</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to throw at</vocabulary>.

You've seen the word 化ける (to transform) before, and here's a related word: 化かす. This means <vocabulary>to bewitch</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to trick</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to deceive</vocabulary>.

Why? In Japanese folklore, foxes, spirits and other yokai often transform in order to bewitch, trick, or deceive humans. To 化かす them, in other words.

This verb is transitive, so it needs a direct object — you bewitch, trick, or deceive someone. You know this because when a fox wants to bewitch someone, they have to <reading>cuss</reading> (かす). They say a magic cuss word that lets them change forms and fool people. Those tricksy foxes…

The kanji version of 話 means <kanji>talk</kanji>. This word also means <vocabulary>talk</vocabulary>, but it means a few other things as well. This can refer to a <vocabulary>speech</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>story</vocabulary> as well. Basically anything that involves a talking session. So, before you go, I hope you stay awhile and listen to my 話.
A 決定 is a "decision." So, when you add する to it you're making it a verb, meaning this word means <vocabulary>to decide</vocabulary>.
You <kanji>exit</kanji> your house and you <kanji>meet</kanji> someone. You didn’t mean to meet them, but it happened anyway. That’s why this word means <vocabulary>to meet by chance</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>distribute</kanji> your <kanji>heart</kanji> around you, it's like your heart is everywhere at once, but not in your body. You feel frantic, you don't know what to do because your heart is out there. This represents the feeling you have when you have <vocabulary>a worry</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>concern</vocabulary>. 心配しないでね！

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>reflect</kanji>. The verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to be reflected</vocabulary>. You're not doing the reflecting directly. You can remember this by thinking how rude (る) it is that someone's reflecting your image using a mirror for everyone outside the dressing room to see.

What's the verb form of <kanji>request</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>to request</vocabulary>. It also is for when you want something (<vocabulary>to want something</vocabulary>), because if you're going <vocabulary>to request something</vocabulary>, you probably want it.

A <kanji>private</kanji> <kanji>iron</kanji> (remember how 鉄 often has to do with railroad tracks and the like? Same goes here) is a <vocabulary>private railway</vocabulary>. There are a good number of these in Japan.
You <kanji>need</kanji> this <kanji>request</kanji> to happen, so you don't just ask nicely, you <vocabulary>demand</vocabulary> it.

You know how 私 can mean <kanji>private</kanji> and how 大 is the first half of 大学? Well, combine those together and you have the shortened version of <vocabulary>private college</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>private university</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>open</kanji> of the <kanji>start</kanji> is the <vocabulary>start</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>beginning</vocabulary>.

Note that 開始 is slightly more formal than 始める.
A <kanji>bend</kanji> in a <kanji>line</kanji> is merely a <vocabulary>curve</vocabulary>.

You sit down to <kanji>solve</kanji> an issue and firmly <kanji>decide</kanji> on your course of action. This process is called <vocabulary>solving</vocabulary>, and it leads to a <vocabulary>solution</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>settlement</vocabulary>.

解決 is about finding a resolution or bringing a matter to a close. It can be used either for small-scale personal problems or for large-scale problems like social and political issues.
When you <kanji>say</kanji> words in a <kanji>language</kanji>, you are speaking a <vocabulary>language</vocabulary>. Not sure what that language is, but since you're saying it it must be real.
Just like the meaning of the kanji (<kanji>fast</kanji>) this adjective also means <vocabulary>fast</vocabulary>.

There is only one place in Japan that has a <kanji>thousand</kanji> <kanji>leaves</kanji> and that's <vocabulary>Chiba</vocabulary>. Picture all of those leaves swirling around you on your vacation to Chiba. Beautiful.

This is a negative form of the verb 思う which is used as an adverb. If you do something without thinking, you do it <vocabulary>unintentionally</vocabulary>. As an adverb, you can put this in front of things to say that you did them <vocabulary>involuntarily</vocabulary>.

立つ means "to stand," and 飲む means "to drink," right? Well, when you do both at the same time, you're <vocabulary>standing and drinking</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>drinking while standing</vocabulary>.

It also refers to casual <vocabulary>standing bar</vocabulary>s where there are no seats — customers stand while having drinks and light snacks.

If you want to <kanji>make</kanji> a <kanji>business</kanji> successful you need to be prepared to do a lot of <vocabulary>work</vocabulary>. Be ready to handle many <vocabulary>task</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>operation</vocabulary>s!

作業 often focuses on individual, hands-on tasks that are undertaken to accomplish a specific objective.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sick</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to get sick</vocabulary>. 

病む means to fall ill in more formal or literary contexts. In casual conversation, especially among younger people, 病む is used to describe someone feeling down, so this can also mean to get depressed.

Note that this word can be transitive and take a direct object, like 心を病む (to be mentally unwell), but can also be used intransitively without a direct object.

You know that the kanji means <kanji>sell</kanji> and the word 売る means "to sell something." 売れる is the intransitive version of this, so this word means for something <vocabulary>to sell</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be sold</vocabulary>.

It can also be used for something <vocabulary>to sell well</vocabulary>, that often results in that thing beginning <vocabulary>to be popular</vocabulary>.

You can remember this because it's <reading>rare</reading> (れる) to see something sell really well to the point where it gets popular!

So you're <kanji>enter</kanji>ing an <kanji>institution</kanji>. But we're not talking about any institution, we're talking specifically about hospitals. So this word means <vocabulary>hospitalization</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>service</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is a place that people go when they're in need of a service. The best place for this is the <vocabulary>town hall</vocabulary>. Everyone goes to this one location to voice their complaints, and in return their needs are serviced by the officials in the town hall.

役場 specifically refers to the administrative office of a town (町) or village (村) rather than a city (市). Depending on the location, it may be also be called a 町役場 or 村役場.

When your <kanji>mouth</kanji> makes <kanji>tone</kanji>s we call it your <vocabulary>tone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>tone of voice</vocabulary>. They're different kinds of sounds you make with your mouth that make you sound happy, sad, mean, etc.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>language</kanji>, so when you do language you're going <vocabulary>to talk</vocabulary> about something. Maybe you're going <vocabulary>to tell</vocabulary> a story, or the truth.

This verb is transitive, so it generally takes a direct object in Japanese, even though the English translations might not.

What <kanji>place</kanji> in your house has most of the <kanji>machine</kanji>s in it? Your <vocabulary>kitchen</vocabulary>! Just think about it. Refrigerator, freezer, dishwasher, stove, microwave, WOW! That's so many. The kitchen definitely has the most machines.
The <kanji>place</kanji> you do your <kanji>farming</kanji> is a <vocabulary>farm</vocabulary>!
Remember how you learned that 大学 means "college?" Well the <kanji>institution</kanji> you go to after college is <vocabulary>graduate school</vocabulary>!
<kanji>Now</kanji> <kanji>morning</kanji> is just another way of saying <vocabulary>this morning</vocabulary>. It's the closest morning to right now!

Picture the <kanji>part</kanji> of your body that makes up your <kanji>neck</kanji>. Are you picturing it? That's a building block that makes up your body. A really important one. If you didn't have that neck, you wouldn't look like a person at all. Sound familiar? It should! Because that part of your neck is a <vocabulary>radical</vocabulary>! Just like part of your neck is a building block of your body, the radical is a building block of kanji. Get it? I sure hope so!
The <kanji>place</kanji> you live <kanji>near</kanji> is your <vocabulary>neighborhood</vocabulary>!
Remember how 足す means "to add?" Add <kanji>calculate</kanji> to that and you'll have <vocabulary>addition</vocabulary>! It's the type of calculation you're doing when you add.

Remember how 引く means "to pull" and "to withdraw"? Well, if you <kanji>calculate</kanji> by pulling or withdrawing one number out of another, you're doing <vocabulary>subtraction</vocabulary>. Kinda like how your bank balance gets lower every time you subtract (withdraw) money from it, you know?
You know 番号 means "number" so add a <kanji>tag</kanji> to it and you have a <vocabulary>numbered tag</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji 点 means <kanji>point</kanji>, but this verb actually means <vocabulary>to be lit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be ignited</vocabulary>. Think of it this way, when a flashlight turns on, it points a beam, of light.

You already learned 点ける, which is for when you turn something on. 点く, on the other hand, is an intransitive verb. That means it happens by itself. Like, "Oh look! The lights came on! That's <reading>cool</reading> (く)!"
A <kanji>mountain</kanji> <kanji>road</kanji> is a <vocabulary>mountain road</vocabulary>! Or a <vocabulary>mountain trail</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>mountain path</vocabulary>.

Something that is <kanji>tall</kanji> in <kanji>degree</kanji>s can either refer to its <vocabulary>altitude</vocabulary>, or to the fact that it's quite <vocabulary>high-level</vocabulary>. 

Note that this can refer to any altitude, even lower ones. But when used to refer to, for example, skills or a technique, it always talks about a high level or degree.

You know 回 means "times," but it can also mean "revolve." You <kanji>revolve</kanji> around an <kanji>answer</kanji> until you're ready to give your <vocabulary>answer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>response</vocabulary> to the question!

回答 refers to responding to a question, inquiry, or request. For example, you use 回答 when answering a questionnaire or letting someone know whether you can attend a party.

The kanji and the vocabulary are exactly the same, so they share meanings as well.

This word is often written in katakana as ページ, especially in informal writing and online. But you'll also see the kanji version, especially to refer to the pages of printed texts and in more formal writing.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>teach</kanji>, and this verb means <vocabulary>to learn something from someone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be taught something</vocabulary>. When you use this verb, you're not learning something by yourself, you're being taught by someone else.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>past</kanji>, and this verb means <vocabulary>to leave</vocabulary>. It should be easy to remember because you know what people say — you leave past in the past.

Things will be <kanji>bright</kanji> <kanji>after</kanji> the next <kanji>day</kanji>. Or you can think of it as adding an 後 in between your 明日. And what comes after tomorrow? It's the <vocabulary>day after tomorrow</vocabulary>.

Remember the small ヶ acting as a counter? Together with <kanji>one</kanji> and <kanji>place</kanji>, it makes this <vocabulary>one place</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>one spot</vocabulary>.

Just like 〜ヶ月, you'll also run into this being written as 一箇所, 一か所, or 一カ所.
A <kanji>straight</kanji> <kanji>line</kanji> is a <vocabulary>straight line</vocabulary>. You know, the shortest distance between two points and all that.

If you make a <kanji>straight</kanji> <kanji>advance</kanji>, you are <vocabulary>going straight ahead</vocabulary>. 

直進 is a slightly formal-sounding word for <vocabulary>direct forward motion</vocabulary>. You'll often hear it in regard to the motion of vehicles, like when your GPS tells you to go straight at a light or an announcement on the train tells you the train will be going straight at the next junction.
